channel.title: Less is better comments on Dull cubicles or dull people?

item.title: "Dull cubicles or dull people?": comment by John Lam
item.description:
Roland, What about my comment about university research labs?

My office in Lash Miller Chemical Laboratories was about as institutional as you could get. We're talking harsh fluorescent lighting, an incredibly noisy ventilation system, a steel desk that I rescued from the loading dock, and a 20 year old swivel chair covered in nasty gray vinyl. Yet there was a Nobel Prize awarded to one of our professors in that very same building.

I'm not saying that the environment is not important. What I am saying is that the people are far more important than the environment. So go ahead and create a better working environment once you've solved the people problem.

item.title: "Dull cubicles or dull people?": comment by Roland Kaufmann
item.description:
Kathy's point was that the introduction of a cubicle environment typically stems from a desire for control, predictability and uniformity, and those factors inhibit creativity and leads to intellectual loss.

It's a myth that good people should be able to perform well regardless of the environment.

item.title: "Dull cubicles or dull people?": comment by J
item.description:
I have to say that I agree with this post. I work in a cubicle setting right now, but I happen to work with people who are interesting, innovative and frequently give me ideas on how to better do my job. I'm actually glad that we don't have office doors; I can turn around, ask a question and have several people give me good answers.

The minus side is that cubicles can get kind of kind of noisy, but that's how it goes.

item.title: "Dull cubicles or dull people?" by jlam
item.description:
Kathy Sierra posted about how cubicles can cause brain damage. Folks, we’re mixing up cause and effect.

Nobody likes cubicles. That’s fine. But simply changing your organization to have beautiful offices with doors that look out over panoramic vistas will not let you create wonderful products if you keep the same people.

It’s the people in your organization that make it dull and lifeless. Let’s face it, the typical graduate student office is about as institutional and ugly as any cube farm, yet remarkable work gets done every day there. Why? It’s the people.

Look around you. Would you rather have a door to keep the bozos out, or would you rather get rid of the bozos?
